stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on debugging, implementing, and polishing the Raphael the Raven boss fight. This involved fixing a critical hitbox bug, programming planetary gravity mechanics for a moon arena, implementing a dynamic difficulty system, creating a cutscene for the transition to the moon, and solving the design problem of how the player gets the star after the fight is over.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a major issue where the boss was invulnerable, discovering it was caused by a bug in his new scaling code that shrank the boss's hitbox to zero.
development_findings.quote: The scale of Raphael Raven was too small. He was scaling down so far that his hitbox was 0.

development_findings.summary: The game's hub world is planned to be Yoshi's Island, with a design inspired by the Yoshi's Tropical Island board from Mario Party, where players use coins to unlock progression like building bridges.
development_findings.quote: The hub world is gonna be Yoshi's Island, of course. You know the Maori Party Board? Yoshi's Tropical Island, where there's fruits everywhere? I want it like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is meticulously balancing the Raphael the Raven boss fight, fine-tuning variables like the boss's speed after an attack to create a fight that is challenging but not frustratingly difficult.
development_findings.quote: It's very hard to find the correct velocity there, because if you set it to 0, the fight is laughably easy, and if you set it like what I have right now, it's a little too hard.

development_findings.summary: Kaze abandoned the idea of using a pipe to return the player from the boss arena due to both the high technical difficulty of programming its orientation on a planet and his feeling that it was a poor design choice.
development_findings.quote: I think the pipe sucks. It sucks programming wise. And it's also not really very visually clear. Why that would happen.

development_findings.summary: As a solution to the return-trip problem, Kaze decided the player will get the star on the moon itself. He accepts that this may allow for a sequence break, subscribing to the philosophy that clever players deserve to be rewarded.
development_findings.quote: If someone figures out a way to ground pound the egg without triggering the bossfight before then they deserve to just get the star like that and skip the bossfight.

development_findings.summary: The game's planetary gravity mechanic is built using quaternions to handle the complex 3D rotations, a technique Kaze believes is accessible to others with some research.
development_findings.quote: If you watch my newest video and you know a little bit about quaternions you can do this too.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the project is 'just over 80 percent' complete.

context_findings.summary: Kaze experiences conflicting community feedback regarding game difficulty, with players finding his levels either too easy or too hard, but never just right.
context_findings.quote: The comments I get on my YouTube is either like, oh wow, this level looks way too easy, or oh wow, this level looks way too hard. No one ever says Kaze, the difficulty of this looks perfect to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong design philosophy against dynamic difficulty based on player health, as he feels it invalidates player progress. He prefers scaling difficulty over time to ensure struggling players can eventually succeed without undermining the challenge.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to make it so that it's actually like... you know how when you play games and there's like a level system... and then the enemies scale to your own level and it's like leveling makes no sense anymore. That's how I feel about scaling it by health. That's why I want to scale it by time.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he is experiencing significant mental distress due to unspecified bureaucratic issues, an external stressor affecting him during development.
context_findings.quote: I'm in mental pain because of bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with community pressure and harassment regarding the game's release date, feeling that he is unfairly cast as the villain for not providing one.
context_findings.quote: You know what the most fucked up part about being a famous romaker is? When people harass me about the release date and I tell them that I want the whole family to... I am the bad guy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to increase his YouTube video output, explicitly linking this decision to the financial need to support his family.
context_findings.quote: I've been thinking I should make a lot more videos. I'm gonna make more money for my family.

biobak.summary: Kaze expresses excitement and reliance on Biobak's graphical work to enhance the atmosphere of the boss fight, envisioning a dynamic, rotating background.
biobak.quote: Dude, Biobak, you can make this fight look so fucking cool with the background. Imagine the whole background here just rotating around.

biobak.summary: Kaze questions one of Biobak's ideas for the boss intro cutscene, revealing a creative dialogue and a potential difference in vision that needed to be reconciled.
biobak.quote: How is he going to obstruct the moon if we do this? He was supposed to block the moon with his face.

biobak.summary: Kaze specifically implemented a technical change in the boss behavior to enable a visual effect that Biobak wanted to create, showing direct technical-artistic collaboration.
biobak.quote: I made him get his color only after he does the stomp so that the effect that you want in Biobak can be made.

zeina.summary: Kaze states that Zeina created the meteor model, which he then slightly modified to better fit the game's mechanics.
zeina.quote: I think Zeina made it. I just made some small changes to make sure it works better here. For my purposes.

zeina.summary: Zeina is responsible for creating the animations for the project, which are a key component currently being worked on before effects and polish can be added.
zeina.quote: Yeah, Zeina is currently working on all the animations we need vfx sfx and camera shakes and stuff like that.

zeina.summary: Zeina sent completed animations to Kaze during the stream, but he decided to implement them in a future session, indicating their direct, ongoing workflow.
zeina.quote: You sent the animations okay um unfortunately that's gonna be a next time thing because it's getting late.

key_stories.title: The Escape from the Moon
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a significant design and technical hurdle in returning the player from the moon-based boss fight. After struggling with a pipe concept and rejecting ideas that felt too much like Mario Galaxy, he pivoted to a simpler, more elegant solution: awarding the star directly on the moon, thus removing the need for a return trip.
key_stories.challenge: After designing a boss fight on a separate moon with planetary gravity, Kaze needed a way to return Mario to the main level that was technically feasible and thematically consistent with Yoshi's Island.
key_stories.process: Kaze first attempted to program a warp pipe that would spawn on the moon's surface but struggled with the complex quaternion math required for correct orientation. He rejected community suggestions like trampolines or launch stars as being too derivative of Mario Galaxy. He concluded that the simplest and most elegant solution was to eliminate the problem by having the star appear directly in the boss arena.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to abandon the return trip entirely. He opted for the boss's egg to hatch on the moon, spawning the star there. This simplified the design, avoided difficult programming, and sidestepped unwanted comparisons to Mario Galaxy.
key_stories.key_quote: Everyone will think of Mario Galaxy when they see this. But it's Yoshi's Island.

key_stories.title: Programming the Planetary Star
key_stories.summary: Implementing the star reward for the moon boss proved technically complex. Kaze had to debug conflicting code and use advanced quaternion math to ensure the star spawned correctly relative to the player on the curved, rotating surface before successfully transitioning it to a collectible state in normal world space.
key_stories.challenge: The star, which spawns after the boss is defeated, needed to appear correctly oriented above Mario on a rotating planet and then detach to become a stationary object in world space for collection.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially struggled with the star spawning in the wrong location or disappearing. He identified conflicting code from two different systems for spawning stars. He then worked through the complex math, realizing he needed to use an inverted quaternion of the planet's rotation to correctly calculate the star's initial spawn position relative to Mario.
key_stories.outcome: After several attempts and debugging pointer issues, Kaze successfully implemented the logic. The star now correctly spawns relative to Mario's position on the moon and then transitions to a fixed position in the world, working as intended.
key_stories.key_quote: Yeah! The star is now in world space. Perfect. Perfect. This is what I wanted.

key_stories.title: Trial and Error Cutscenes
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream on the tedious, iterative process of creating the cutscene for the moon transition. Through trial and error, he adjusted camera paths and character movement functions to achieve a cinematic effect he was happy with, highlighting the hands-on, non-glamorous work of cutscene creation.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to create a smooth, cinematic cutscene of both Mario and the boss, Raphael the Raven, flying from the main platform to the moon arena.
key_stories.process: Kaze repeatedly tweaked the cutscene's implementation, adjusting character movement curves with custom math functions (going beyond simple smoothstep) and repositioning camera focus points. He iterated between focusing on Mario, the moon, and both characters to find the most visually appealing composition, demonstrating the tedious nature of in-engine cinematic work.
key_stories.outcome: Through a process of trial and error, Kaze achieved a camera path and character movement that he was satisfied with, though he acknowledges it's not final and still requires animations and other effects.
key_stories.key_quote: This making cutscenes like this sucks.
